moves.1. Nf3 d5 2. c4 dxc4 3. Qa4+ Nc6 4. Qxc4: The starting position. Both sides have castled but still need to complete their development.
moves.9. Nc3 Na5 10. Qd3 a6 11. b3 Nd5 12. Nxd: The first skirmish leaves material still even.
moves.14. Bb2 Nc6 15. Rfe1: Development is now completed, and we enter the middle game proper.
moves.19... Qf6 20. Ne1 Rae8 21. Qe2 Nb4 22. B: Some slow maneuvering produces, as yet, no advantage for either side.
moves.23... a5 24. a3 Nc6 25. Bb2 Bxg3: Some action! Black elects to sacrifice a piece for two Pawns to open lines for an attack on my King.
moves.26. fxg3 Re4xe3 27. Ng2: The best way to refute a sacrifice, Steinitz said, is to accept it. So I do, and now I try to drive back Black's attacking efforts.
moves.27... Re3e2 28. Qc3 Re8e4 29. Rce1: I offer to swap down, to reduce the attacking power.
moves.29... Re2xe1 30. Rxe1 Rxe1+ 31. Qxe1: The swap is completed, and the end-game stage begins. In spite of a slight material deficit, Black still has good drawing chances.
moves.35. dxe5 c5: With his Q still on the board and a passed QP, Black can still drag on his resistance for a while.
moves.36. e6: Black must neutralize this Pawn at once. If he lets me get  another Queen...
moves.37. Qc1: Now it's apparent Black's last move was a tactical error.
moves.37... Qxb3: Obviously he can't afford to trade Queens...
moves.38. e7: ...but now I get a second one.
moves.39... Kg7 40. Ne2 Qd5+ 41. Kg1: Black resigns, as he has run out of checks.
